Situation1: They support a mentee facing a high-stakes project that could determine their future career trajectory.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning groceries with practiced ease, my mind only half on the beeping rhythm. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from Jamie, my mentee. “Can you talk? The project’s falling apart.” I glanced at the clock. Jamie’s deadline was tonight, and I’d promised to help her navigate this crucial moment. As a mentor, I was supposed to be her anchor, the one who encouraged her to push through and grow. But right now, I was also a cashier, expected to smile and chat with Mrs. Lee about her grandkids, to help Mr. Patel find the right change, to be present and pleasant for every customer. The line grew, and so did the knot in my stomach. I could see Jamie’s anxious words on my screen, but I could also see the expectant faces in front of me. I felt torn, pulled by the weight of two worlds—one needing my guidance, the other my undivided attention. My hands moved automatically, but my mind wrestled with the impossible choice: who needed me more right now?
